fields.name: Goldberry
fields.description: Tom Bombadil's wife. Sometimes called the River Daughter.

fields.name: Barrow Wight
fields.description: An unnamed barrow wight who captures Frodo, Sam, Merry, and Pippin

fields.text:
The Road goes ever on and on
    Down from the door where it began. 
Now far ahead the Road has gone, 
    And I must follow, if I can, 
Pursuing it with eager feet, 
    Until it joins some larger way 
Where many paths and errands meet. 
    And whither then? I cannot say.
fields.context: Sung by Bilbo as he set out on the road after his 111th birthday party.

fields.text:
One Ring to rule them all, One Ring to find them, 
One Ring to bring them all and in the darkness bind them.
fields.context: Translation of inscription on the One Ring as recited by Gandalf after throwing the ring into the fire to reveal its secrets.

fields.text:
Three Rings for the Elven-kings under the sky, 
    Seven for the Dwarf-lords in their halls of stone,
Nine for Mortal Men doomed to die,
    One for the Dark Lord on his dark throne
In the Land of Mordor where the Shadows lie.
    One Ring to rule them all, One Ring to find them, 
One Ring to bring them all and in the darkness bind them
    In the Land of Mordor where the Shadows lie.
fields.context: Elven-verse, "long known from Elven-lore", from which the inscription on the One Ring was taken.

fields.text:
The Road goes ever on and on
    Down from the door where it began.
Now far ahead the Road has gone,
    And I must follow, if I can, 
Pursuing it with weary feet, 
    Until it joins some larger way, 
Where many paths and errands meet. 
    And whither then? I cannot say.
fields.context: Recited by Frodo after he, Sam, and Pippin started their journey. It's identical to Bilbo's version with one notable difference: instead of "eager feet" Frodo says "weary feet".

fields.text:
Upon the hearth the fire is red, 
Beneath the roof there is a bed; 
But not yet weary are our feet, 
Still round the corner we may meet 
A sudden tree or standing stone 
That none have seen but we alone. 
    Tree and flower and leaf and grass, 
    Let them pass! Let them pass! 
    Hill and water under sky, 
    Pass them by! Pass them by! 
  
Still round the corner there may wait 
A new road or a secret gate, 
And though we pass them by today,
Tomorrow we may come this way 
And take the hidden paths that run 
Towards the Moon or to the Sun. 
    Apple, thorn, and nut and sloe, 
    Let them go! Let them go! 
    Sand and stone and pool and dell, 
    Fare you well! Fare you well! 
  
Home is behind, the world ahead, 
And there are many paths to tread 
Through shadows to the edge of night, 
Until the stars are all alight. 
Then world behind and home ahead, 
We’ll wander back to home and bed. 
    Mist and twilight, cloud and shade, 
    Away shall fade! Away shall fade! 
    Fire and lamp, and meat and bread, 
    And then to bed! And then to bed!
fields.context: A "walking song" composed by Bilbo Baggins and sung by Frodo Baggins as he, Merry, and Pippin traveled.

fields.text:
Snow-white! Snow-white! 
    O Lady clear! O Queen beyond the Western Seas! 
O Light to us that wander here 
    Amid the world of woven trees! 

Gilthoniel! O Elbereth! 
    Clear are thy eyes and bright thy breath! 
Snow-white! Snow-white! We sing to thee 
    In a far land beyond the Sea. 

O stars that in the Sunless Year 
    With shining hand by her were sown, 
In windy fields now bright and clear 
    We see your silver blossom blown! 
  
O Elbereth! Gilthoniel! 
    We still remember, we who dwell 
In this far land beneath the trees, 
    Thy starlight on the Western Seas.
fields.context: Song sung by the first elves the Party meets while traveling. Frodo heard the song before ever seeing the elves.

fields.text:
Ho! Ho! Ho! to the bottle I go 
To heal my heart and drown my woe. 
Rain may fall and wind may blow, 
And many miles be still to go, 
But under a tall tree I will lie, 
And let the clouds go sailing by.
fields.context: Song sung by Frodo, Merry, and Pippin while traveling.

fields.text:
Sing hey! for the bath at close of day 
that washes the weary mud away! 
A loon is he that will not sing: 
O! Water Hot is a noble thing! 

O! Sweet is the sound of falling rain, 
and the brook that leaps from hill to plain; 
but better than rain or rippling streams 
is Water Hot that smokes and steams. 

O! Water cold we may pour at need 
down a thirsty throat and be glad indeed; 
but better is Beer, if drink we lack, 
and Water Hot poured down the back. 

O! Water is fair that leaps on high 
in a fountain white beneath the sky; 
but never did fountain sound so sweet 
as splashing Hot Water with my feet!
fields.context: One of Bilbo's "bath songs" sung by Pippin while he, Sam, and Frodo took a bath at Frodo's house is Crickhollow.

fields.text:
Farewell we call to hearth and hall!
Though wind may blow and rain may fall, 
We must away ere break of day 
Far over wood and mountain tall. 

To Rivendell, where Elves yet dwell 
In glades beneath the misty fell, 
Through moor and waste we ride in haste, 
And whither then we cannot tell.

With foes ahead, behind us dread, 
Beneath the sky shall be our bed, 
Until at last our toil be passed, 
Our journey done, our errand sped. 

We must away! We must away! 
We ride before the break of day!
fields.context: Song sung at the Crickhollow house after Sam, Merry, and Pippin reveal their conspiracy to accompany Frodo.

fields.text:
O! Wanderers in the shadowed land 
despair not! For though dark they stand, 
all woods there be must end at last, 
and see the open sun go past: 
the setting sun, the rising sun, 
the day’s end, or the day begun. 
For east or west all woods must fail …
fields.context: Song sung by Frodo while he, Merry, Sam, and Pippin walked through the Dark Forest. He meant it as a song of encouragement but "his voice sank to a murmur"

fields.text:
Hey! Come merry dol! derry dol! My darling! 
Light goes the weather-wind and the feathered starling. 
Down along under Hill, shining in the sunlight, 
Waiting on the doorstep for the cold starlight, 
There my pretty lady is, River-woman’s daughter, 
Slender as the willow-wand, clearer than the water. 
Old Tom Bombadil water-lilies bringing 
Comes hopping home again. Can you hear him singing? 
Hey! Come merry dol! derry dol! and merry-o, 
Goldberry, Goldberry, merry yellow berry-o! 
Poor old Willow-man, you tuck your roots away! 
Tom’s in a hurry now. Evening will follow day. 
Tom’s going home again water-lilies bringing. 
Hey! Come derry dol! Can you hear me singing?
fields.context: Song heard by Frodo and company just before seeing Tom Bombadil in the Dark Forest.

fields.text:
Hey dol! merry dol! ring a dong dillo! 
Ring a dong! hop along! fal lal the willow! 
Tom Bom, jolly Tom, Tom Bombadillo!
fields.context: Part of a song that Frodo and Company heard while despairing in the Dark Forest, the first thing they ever heard Tom Bombadil say.

fields.text:
Hop along, my little friends, up the Withywindle! 
Tom’s going on ahead candles for to kindle. 
Down west sinks the Sun: soon you will be groping. 
When the night-shadows fall, then the door will open, 
Out of the window-panes light will twinkle yellow. 
Fear no alder black! Heed no hoary willow! 
Fear neither root nor bough! Tom goes on before you. 
Hey now! merry dol! We’ll be waiting for you!
fields.context: Song sung by Tom Bombadil as he leads the company to his home.

fields.text:
Now let the song begin! Let us sing together 
Of sun, stars, moon and mist, rain and cloudy weather, 
Light on the budding leaf, dew on the feather, 
Wind on the open hill, bells on the heather, 
Reeds by the shady pool, lilies on the water: 
Old Tom Bombadil and the River-daughter!
fields.context: As the company approached Tom Bombadil's house, they heard a new voice, singing this song to greet them. It was sung by Tom Bombadil's wife, Goldberry.

fields.text:
Hey! Come derry dol! Hop along, my hearties! 
Hobbits! Ponies all! We are fond of parties. 
Now let the fun begin! Let us sing together!
fields.context: Song sung by Tom Bombadil as the company approached his house.

fields.text:
O slender as a willow-wand! O clearer than clear water! 
O reed by the living pool! Fair River-daughter! 
O spring-time and summer-time, and spring again after! 
O wind on the waterfall, and the leaves’ laughter!
fields.context:
When entering Tom Bombadil's house and greeting by Goldberry, Frodo was enchanted by Goldberry and recited this verse, much to his own surprise. To that, Goldberry responds, "I had not heard that folk of the Shire were so sweet-tongued. But I see that you are an Elf-friend; the light in your eyes and the ring in your voice tells it."  

Though not technically a "recitation" as he seems to have spoken extemporaneously, Tolkien presented as a verse.

fields.text:
Old Tom Bombadil is a merry fellow; 
Bright blue his jacket is, and his boots are yellow.
fields.context: While sitting in Tom Bombadil's house, the company would hear Tom Bombadil singing this while doing something else in another part of the house.

fields.text:
I had an errand there: gathering water-lilies, 
green leaves and lilies white to please my pretty lady, 
the last ere the year’s end to keep them from the winter, 
to flower by her pretty feet till the snows are melted. 
Each year at summer’s end I go to find them for her, 
in a wide pool, deep and clear, far down Withywindle; 
there they open first in spring and there they linger latest. 
By that pool long ago I found the River-daughter, 
fair young Goldberry sitting in the rushes. 
Sweet was her singing then, and her heart was beating!

And that proved well for you – for now I shall no longer 
go down deep again along the forest-water,
not while the year is old. Nor shall I be passing 
Old Man Willow’s house this side of spring-time, 
not till the merry spring, when the River-daughter 
dances down the withy-path to bathe in the water.
fields.context: After eating dinner their first night in Tom Bombadil's house, the company along with Tom sat by the fire. Tom seemed to be nodding off to sleep, but he sang this song. It speaks of his first meeting Goldberry.

fields.text:
Ho! Tom Bombadil, Tom Bombadillo! 
By water, wood and hill, by the reed and willow, 
By fire, sun and moon, harken now and hear us! 
Come, Tom Bombadil, for our need is near us!
fields.context: The night before the company leaves Tom Bombadil's home to continue their journey, Tom offers them advice on the coming trip. "Then he taught them a rhyme to sing, if they should by ill-luck fall into any danger or difficulty the next day." As it turns out, they will use this verse after being captured by Barrow wights.

fields.text:
Cold be hand and heart and bone, 
and cold be sleep under stone: 
never more to wake on stony bed, 
never, till the Sun fails and the Moon is dead. 
In the black wind the stars shall die, 
and still on gold here let them lie, 
till the dark lord lifts his hand 
over dead sea and withered land.
fields.context: While held inside a barrow after being capture by a barrow wight, Frodo heard what he first thought to be a song, but then "perceived that it had changed into an incantation."

fields.text:
Ho! Tom Bombadil, Tom Bombadillo!
By water, wood and hill, by the reed and willow, 
By fire, sun and moon, harken now and hear us! 
Come, Tom Bombadil, for our need is near us!
fields.context: While still being held by the barrow wight, "All at once back into his mind, from which it had disappeared with the first coming of the fog, came the memory of the house down under the Hill, and of Tom singing. He remembered the rhyme that Tom had taught them. In a small desperate voice he began:"

fields.text:
Old Tom Bombadil is a merry fellow, 
Bright blue his jacket is, and his boots are yellow. 
None has ever caught him yet, for Tom, he is the master: 
His songs are stronger songs, and his feet are faster.
fields.context: After reciting the rhyme Tom Bombadil taught him should they fall into trouble, "There was a sudden deep silence, in which Frodo could hear his heart beating. After a long slow moment he heard plain, but far away, as if it was coming down through the ground or through thick walls, an answering voice singing:"

fields.text:
Get out, you old Wight! Vanish in the sunlight! 
Shrivel like the cold mist, like the winds go wailing,
Out into the barren lands far beyond the mountains! 
Come never here again! Leave your barrow empty! 
Lost and forgotten be, darker than the darkness, 
Where gates stand for ever shut, till the world is mended.
fields.context: After being summoned by Frodo's cry for help, Tom Bombadil banishes the wight holding the company with this verse. Then, "At these words there was a cry and part of the inner end of the chamber fell in with a crash. Then there was a long trailing shriek, fading away into an unguessable distance; and after that silence."

fields.text:
Wake now my merry lads! Wake and hear me calling! 
Warm now be heart and limb! The cold stone is fallen; 
Dark door is standing wide; dead hand is broken.
Night under Night is flown, and the Gate is open!
fields.context: After being rescued from the barrow wight by Tom Bombadil, Sam, Merry, and Pippin were laid on the grass outside the barrow, still unconscious. Tom sang this song to revive them. "To Frodo’s great joy the hobbits stirred, stretched their arms, rubbed their eyes, and then suddenly sprang up. They looked about in amazement, first at Frodo, and then at Tom standing large as life on the barrow-top above them; and then at themselves in their thin white rags, crowned and belted with pale gold, and jingling with trinkets."

fields.text:
Hey! now! Come hoy now! Whither do you wander? 
Up, down, near or far, here, there or yonder? 
Sharp-ears, Wise-nose, Swish-tail and Bumpkin, 
White-socks my little lad, and old Fatty Lumpkin!
fields.context: After rescuing the company from the barrow wight, Tom Bombadil leaves them for a while, singing this song as he departs. He returns to them with the company's five ponies and one of his own, Fatty Lumpkin.

fields.text:
Tom’s country ends here: he will not pass the borders. 
Tom has his house to mind, and Goldberry is waiting!
fields.context: After recuperating from the barrow wight captivity, the company continues toward the East Road, accompanied by Tom, riding Fatty Lumpkin. As they near their destination (Bree), the company begs Tom to at least come as far as the inn in Bree for a drink, but he declines, saying these lines.
